instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> external image only
threads.message:
This one came in with liquid damage  that was repaired by someone else. <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and some components around it were replaced, flux was still on there.

This board powers up fine and shows an image on external display, but not on the built-in screen. No corrosion around J8500 or the board to board cable. I've tried a known working display, but nothing.

Backlight is not coming on, and there is no image visible when viewing with a flashlight.

I compared J8500 pins to those on a working board in diode mode; they're the same.

I suspected <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> as its somewhat close to <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and replaced it, but no change.

Stuff measured: [TABLE="border: 0, cellspacing: 0"]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>BUF_EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]3,4V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]0V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[/TABLE]
[TABLE="border: 0, cellspacing: 0"]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> input check[/TD]
 			[TD="align: right"] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: right"]3,3V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_A</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: right"]5,1V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: right"]12,8V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[/TABLE]

As I understand it, <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> needs to be lower than 12,8V for <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> to open up. I'm guessing that <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> simply isnt 'told' to activate. Any help be welcome!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> external image only
threads.message:
Image must come on before backlight.
So you don't have a backlight issue.

Do you get both 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> voltages?
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> should go high at same time.

Liquid ingress on backlight area is not good at all.
Data lines from internal copper layers could be affected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> external image only
threads.message:
Ah, image before BL. Didnt know that, thanks.

Measured (with display attached): [TABLE="border: 0, cellspacing: 0"]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: right"]3,3V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: right"]5,1V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: right"]3,3V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[/TABLE]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> external image only
threads.message:
Look s like CPU issue then.
Its internal LCD output is bad, if no image for sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> external image only
threads.message: Well, that sucks. Can you think of a way to make it think the internal display is actually the external one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> external image only
threads.message:
PCH detects intrernal LCD, as voltages and hot plug signal stay high.
eDP data bus is porobably damaged...
